ARTICLE.TITLE: American, Southwest Airlines seek approval to resume flights to Costa Rica
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Dallas-Fort Worth-based American and Southwest Airlines have joined four other carriers in seeking approval from Costa Rican officials to let them resume flights from U.S. cities.

Costa Rica was set to reopen two of its airports on Aug. 1, including the Juan Santamaría International Airport in San Jose and the Daniel Oduber Quirós International Airport in Liberia. The Juan Santamaría airport is one of the busiest in Central America.

When officials announced the reopening in late July, it said citizens of the U.K., Canada and the European Union would be permitted to enter Costa Rica if they provided negative COVID-19 test results, according to Reuters.

A spokesperson for Southwest Airlines said the Dallas-based airline hopes to restart service to Liberia in the Northwest Guanacaste province of Costa Rica in November with once daily service to and from Houston Hobby Airport, pending approval from Costa Rican officials. The Liberia airport is popular with tourists visiting the Pacific Ocean coast and western Costa Rica.

Texans would be able to connect from Houston Hobby to Dallas.

American Airlines is seeking approval to fly “a few” repatriation flights between DFW Airport and the Santamaría airport in August, and flights from Miami International Airport to San Jose on Sept. 9, according to company spokeswoman Nichelle Barrett.

United, Alaska, Spirit and Volaris airlines have also made proposals to resume flights to the Central American country, according to QCostaRica, citing Costa Rican officials.

Still, only residents of foreign countries that have “controlled the spread of the coronavirus” will be permitted to enter Costa Rica, according to the U.S. Embassy there. The country has reported 24,508 cases of COVID-19 as of Aug. 11.

Besides Mexico and Brazil, air travel to countries in Central and South America remains mostly off limits to U.S. citizens. Those that allow it have instituted requirements ranging from providing proof of a negative COVID-19 test to quarantining for two weeks upon arrival.

Americans represent the largest group of international travelers to Costa Rica, with 1.33 million arrivals last year, according to Costa Rica tourism data. That was up 5.5% over 2018. In all, Costa Rica saw 3.14 million foreign visitors in 2019.
